title: ‘Mom Genes’ Review: The Making of a Mother
sub_head: To experience pregnancy, childbirth and maternity is to take part in a ‘cellular-level revolution that rebuilds the female brain.’
body:
I never felt the urge to hold someone else’s baby. The cooing infants of others always seemed too fragile to be worth the hassle; I suppose I always worried I would accidentally drop one. When I became pregnant myself, on purpose but rather late, I was rattled by my resentment of the way my life and my increasingly scrutinized body morphed to accommodate this new stowaway.
I could not predict that the moment I met my son, I would weep with primal gratitude. In the face of this 8-pound, 10-ounce reality, no longer an abstract source of dread, all I wanted was to hold him close and snuggle.
What the heck happened to me?
According to Abigail Tucker, a bestselling science writer and the author of “Mom Genes,” this transformation can be chalked up to my “maternal instinct.” The term “instinct” here can be misleading: Ms. Tucker does not mean to imply that I suddenly, magically knew how to care for my child. Instead she is describing “a transformed mental state, a new repertoire of senses, feelings, impulses” that more or less hijack mothers during pregnancy and never quite let up.
“Mom Genes” is an impressive synthesis of the current state of “mom science,” a fairly new and fecund field that mostly considers how mothers are different from other people and similar to each other. A mother of four herself, Ms. Tucker admits that she long viewed motherhood as “an elective lifestyle rather than a biological predicament.” But in researching this book, she has come to see maternity as far more fascinating and dramatic: a “cellular-level revolution that rebuilds the female brain.”
